results.title: Through my eyes (TEFC): Kilkenny Primary School, South Australia
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Timothy Read and Donald Crombie
results.brief_description: Kilkenny Primary School is an open-plan school in Adelaide. A bright decor with red carpets, a straw covered ceiling, and splashes of bright colors provides the setting for the activities of senior primary pupils and their teachers. The implementation of a team teaching approach, individual and group work, and the integration of activities and ideas are illustrated in the film. (Teacher education)

results.title: Through Grandpa's eyes
results.brief_description: Based on a book by Patricia MacLachlan. A warmly moving film that captures the special bond between a blind man and his grandson. Young Johnny’s grandpa now old and blind can only imagine the sights that surround him. However, grandpa’s blindness often allows him to see in ways incomprehensible to the sighted.

results.title: Through different eyes
results.brief_description: Melbourne is the headquarters for many multinational companies, and because of its strategic position has the busiest seaport in Australia. With the Victorian Government offering worthwhile assistance to suitable potential migrants, more and more overseas business people recognising the potential opportunities available, are opting to move to this state. Three such men, Alan Ang (Singapore), Heinz Karona (Germany) and Dr Robert Deutcher (USA) discuss the assistance offered by the Victorian Government, climate, education, quality of life, cost of living, as some of the reasons determining the decision to migrate.

results.title: Through conflict to negotiation
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Barrie Howells, John Kemeny, Bonnie Sherr Klein and Peter Pearson
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Challenge for change”
A community action group in Rochester, New York, confronts the community’s largest employer on the issue of corporate responsibility and the employment of minority groups.

results.title: Through a looking glass; Drama is -
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development and Vincent O'Donnell
results.brief_description: Two drama education programs: “Through a looking glass” shows the major concepts underlaying drama in education and how the teacher can participate with the student in the dramatic process. “Drama is -” explores the ways in which drama can be used as a method to teach many subject areas.

results.title: Through a glass darkly
results.creator_credit: Svensk Filmindustri, Allan Ekelund and Ingmar Bergman
results.brief_description: Bergman’s “Through a glass darkly” centres on the lives of four characters. Karen (Harriet Andersson) suffers from schizophrenia and has just returned from hospital. She lives on a remote island in the Baltic with her husband Martin (Max Von Sydow) and brother Minus (Lars Passgard). David (Gunnar Bjornstrand), their father, is a novelist who returns from Switzerland to visit them. Gradually the severity of Karen’s illness becomes apparent to them all. Despite it’s dark subject matter “Through a glass darkly” is mesmerising to watch thanks to the outstanding performances by the four actors as well Sven Nykvist’s beautiful cinematography. Winner of 1961 Academy Award for Best Foreign Film. In Swedish with english subtitles.

results.title: Through a broken pane
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Wolf Koenig and Blake James
results.brief_description: From an artist’s sketchbook and a poet’s memories, a recollection of life in a country school, a place now derelict and vacant but alive with past associations. The film employs various forms of animation to give life and activity to the old building, looking in through the broken windows at the old desks, the clock on the wall, and looking out at the countryside and what a child might remember of what happened there.

results.title: Through a blue lens
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Gillian Darling Kovanic and Veronica Alice Mannix
results.brief_description: Six Vancouver policemen have formed the Odd Squad - a team of officers dedicated to capturing the thoughts and feelings of drug addicts in Vancouver’s Downtown Eastside as a means of preventing drug use by young people. They initially began with a camera that captured vignettes with an anti drug message, then moved onto a movie camera so that addicts could tell a story in their own words. Most of the addicts are willing to take part in the anti drug war in the only way they can - by courageously using themselves as examples. Through the process the Odd Squad develop tenuous relationships with the addicts and discover that the people they meet had lives prior to their addiction. This powerful educational tool contains coarse language and graphic scenes. Preview is recommended.
